where: Institute for Molecular Bioscience, The University of Queensland
additional_info: Supervisor: Dr Ann-Marie Patch. Focused on understanding cancer genome morphology through analysis of next generation sequencing data.

where: School of Biological Sciences, The University of Queensland
additional_info: Supervisors: Associate Professor Sandie Degnan, Dr Selene Fernandez Valverde, and Simone Higgie. Duties included developing a computational pipeline for detection of lateral genetic transfer in marine sponge.

where: School of Biological Sciences, The University of Queensland
additional_info: Supervisors: Associate Professor Sandie Degnan and Simone Higgie. Project focused on using phylogenetics to define the origin of conserved protein domains identified as potentially having arisen via lateral genetic transfer in marine sponge.

where: Institute for Molecular Bioscience, The University of Queensland
additional_info: Supervisors: Professor Mark Ragan and Dr Cheong Xin Chan. Project focuses on using next generation sequencing data to define a set of core Symbiodinium genes vital to the maintenance of coral-dinoflagellate symbiosis.

where: Institute for Molecular Bioscience, The University of Queensland
additional_info: Supervisors: Professor Mark Ragan and Dr Cheong Xin Chan. Project focuses on using next generation sequencing data to study the genome evolution of dinoflagellate algae, with a focus on the lineage associated with coral symbiosis.

where: Department of Biochemistry and Microbiology, Rutgers University
additional_info: Supervisor: Distinguished Professor Debashish Bhattacharya. Project focuses on using integrated multi-omics data to study plastid evolution and endosymbiosis in the photosynthetic amoeba Paulinella.

what: Selected for the Advanced Study Program in Science (ASPinS; based on academic merit)
Dean’s Commendation for Academic Excellence (achieved a GPA over 6.6)
Top poster prize at the IMB Research Higher Degree Student Symposium
Won best pitch prize at the UQ Idea Hub
Registration award for Society for Molecular Biology & Evolution (SMBE) 2018
2019 Dean’s Award for Outstanding Higher Degree by Research Theses

additional_info: Duties included guiding undergraduate chemistry students through an advanced set of research-focused practicals, with the aim of developing their critical and experimental thinking.

Duties included organizing and running first year science student introduction and social engagement events designed to inform students about study/research opportunities available at The University of Queensland.
Duties included planning and leading multiple weekly tutorial sessions, each comprising 20-30+ students.
Participated in a series of workshops to develop skills in the areas of research commercialisation and idea development.
Participated in a two-day intensive workshop to develop skills and knowledge in the field of research commercialisation. Focus on strong cooperation with UniQuest, UQ’s commercialisation subdivision.
Duties included assisting students with the completion of set questions and marking of assignments.
Duties included designing and developing assessment material for the course and organising marking of assignments.

Conducted lectures on de novo next-generation sequencing, genome and transcriptome sequencing, and metagenomics in a join undergraduate and postgraduate course titled “Fundamentals of Microbial Genomics”. Also assisted in designing and marking student exam questions and students’ oral presentations.

what: Our paper ["Why is primary endosymbiosis so rare?"](https://nph.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/nph.17478) covered by [Rutgers Newsroom](https://sebsnjaesnews.rutgers.edu/2020/10/bhattacharya-lab-analyzes-genome-sequence-of-paulinella-shedding-light-on-the-origin-of-photosynthesis/)

Our paper ["Third Party Tracking in the Mobile Ecosystem"](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32790833/) covered by [Rutgers Today](https://www.rutgers.edu/news/new-study-sheds-light-evolution-photosynthesis)

Our paper ["Retrotransposition facilitated the establishment of a primary plastid in the thecate amoeba *Paulinella*"](https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.2121241119) covered by [Rutgers Research](https://research.rutgers.edu/news/dynamic-evolution-photosynthetic-organelle)

Article on our short film ["The Coral Holobiont Response to Climate Change"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TWtQn2thSrM) which won Best Trailer in the Kiez Berlin Film Festival. Covered by [Rutgers Research](https://research.rutgers.edu/news/rutgers-researcher-aims-protect-and-regenerate-corals-through-coral-genomics-500k-nsf-grant)

additional_info: a workflow for the prediction of protein-coding genes in dinoflagellate genomes. It integrates evidence from multiple sources, including transcriptome, proteome, and other ab initio gene prediction tools.
